others to respond to an alarm device.
   (g)   "Chief of Police" means the duly appointed Chief of the Willoughby
Hills Police Department, or his authorized representative, and for the purposes
of this chapter, shall be construed to include the Chief of the Willoughby
Hills Fire Department (herein referred to as the "Fire Chief") or his
authorized representative.
   (h)   "Residence" means single family dwellings, two family, double or
duplex houses, multiple houses, and apartment buildings or multifamily
dwellings as those terms are defined in Chapter 1131 of the Codified
Ordinances.
      (Ord. 1998-70. Passed 12-10-98.)
715.03 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE BY ALARM BUSINESSES. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
715.03 was repealed by Ordinance 2024-065, passed December 12, 2024)
715.04 ALARM AGENT REQUIRED TO POSSESS IDENTIFICATION CARD.
   Each employee of an alarm business having reason to be physically present
within the City of Willoughby Hills on official alarm business shall have in
their possession an identification card issued by their alarm business
employer. The identification card shall
include the following: employee's name, address, date of birth, recent
photograph, and an
inscription signifying that the card is the property of the alarm business.
(Ord. 1998-70. Passed 12-10-98.)
715.05 ANNUAL BUSINESS LICENSE; FEE; PENALTY FOR NONRENEWAL; NEW LICENSES.
(REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
715.05 was repealed by Ordinance 2024-066, passed December 12, 2024)
715.06 AUTHORITY TO INSTALL ALARMS.
   Any residence or business located within the City of Willoughby Hills may be
equipped with an emergency alarm for the purpose of detecting and signaling the
presence of a fire or unauthorized intrusion at such location, but no such
installation shall be made after the effective date of this section unless all
requirements of this chapter have been met. Existing installations, whether
residential or otherwise, shall also be subject to the requirements of this
chapter, including those requirements pertaining to obtaining licensing by the
alarm business.
(Ord. 1998-70. Passed 12-10-98.)
715.07  DIFFERENTIATION BETWEEN FIRE AND INTRUSION.
   No person shall install, or allow to be installed, any alarm covered by
Section 715.06 which detects both fire and unauthorized intrusion unless such
unit shall also be capable of transmitting a signal for fire different from the
signal for unauthorized intrusion in a manner in which the person monitoring
the alarm can readily ascertain whether the signaled cause is fire or
unauthorized intrusion.
(Ord. 1998-70. Passed 12-10-98.)
715.08 ALARMS CONNECTED DIRECTLY TO POLICE STATION; PERMIT; FEE.
   (a)    Upon proper application by any financial institution to connect
installed equipment to the Willoughby Hills Police Station to receive emergency
alarms, the Chief of Police or his authorized representative may issue a permit
for such connection.
 
   (b)    Connection to the police or fire alarm panel shall be contingent upon
the applicant having obtained permission from the company which maintains the
alarm panel in the station to make such connection, provided that such company
shall not deny permission if the equipment is compatible, and proper charges
are paid to such company.
 
   (c)    No unit shall be installed or connected after the effective date of
this chapter unless it is approved by the Fire Chief if designed to detect
smoke or fire or by the Police Chief if designed to detect unauthorized
intrusion, or both if designed to detect both smoke, fire, heat, or
unauthorized intrusion. The Building Inspector or his representative shall
inspect and approve the electrical installation and equipment of the applicant,
or, upon failure to approve, shall state the reasons therefor, which the person
making the installation shall forthwith correct.
   (d)    The City shall, within its capabilities, endeavor to accommodate
every reasonable application for connection to the police or fire alarm panels.
   (e)    Each alarm connected to the police or fire alarm console shall be
charged a one time permit fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) payable to
the City, to cover the cost of installation and in addition thereto a
maintenance fee of one hundred twenty dollars ($120.00) per year payable
annually, in advance, to the City. All such payments shall become due January 1
of each year. All alarms connected to the City console after February 1 of each
year shall be paid in advance for the ensuing year at the rate of ten dollars
($10.00) per month beginning the first day of the month of such application.
Failure of the user to pay the annual maintenance charge by February 1 shall
result in a late charge of one and one-half percent (1 1/2%) per month per
connection. Failure of the user to pay the annual maintenance fee with computed
late charge by May 1 may result in the disconnection of the alarm or alarms
from the Police Department panel. There shall be no additional fee for a permit
for installation of any alarm connected to the police or fire alarm panel as of
the date of passage of this chapter.
   (f)    Any alarm currently connected to the Police Department panel shall
not be removed as a result of the passage of this chapter.
(Ord. 1998-70. Passed 12-10-98.)
715.09 FALSE ALARMS; WARNING; ADMINISTRATIVE FEE; ORDER; NUISANCE.
   (a)   No person shall fail to maintain equipment under his control designed
to give
alarms of any type at less than the level of maintenance necessary to prevent
false alarms from being emitted.
 
   (b)    The Chief of Police or his designee shall issue warnings and order
the assessment of administrative fees against the user and/or provider upon the
schedules provided in Section
715.10(c) and (d). The administrative fee is a partial reimbursement to the
City for the cost of receiving and responding to the false alarm. The number of
false alarms shall be counted within the twelve (12) month calendar year. The
Chief of Police shall issue the guidelines which he intends to follow in the
administration of this section.
   (c)   The following fee schedule shall apply for false alarms in R
Residential
 
Number       Action Taken
1 and 2      Warning letter to user /provider, no charge
3 through 6  $25.00 fee to user and/or provider
7 through 12 $50.00 fee to user and/or provider
Over 12      $100.00 fee to user and/or provider
 
   (d)    The following fee schedule shall apply in all districts other than R
Residential:
 
Number       Action Taken
1 and 2      Warning letter to user/provider, no charge
3 through 6  $50.00 fee to user and/or provider
7 through 12 $100.00 fee to user and/or provider
Over 12      $200.00 fee to user and/or provider
 
   (e)    The Chief of Police may waive all or parts of the above schedules for
a newly installed alarm system during thirty (30) days immediately following
the completion of the installation to a maximum of three (3) false alarms.
   (f)    Notwithstanding the fine to be assessed as set forth above, no charge
shall be made for a false alarm to which there is no response by the Police or
Fire Departments, nor when the cause has been proven as an act of God, or as
defined in Section
715.02(b).
 
   (g)    The Chief of Police may order that the user or provider prove that
the cause of the false alarm notification has been remedied.
   (h)    If the user fails to pay the administrative fee within thirty (30)
days thereof, the Chief of Police shall report the delinquency to the Director
of Finance, who shall report the same to Council, which may thereupon assess
the cost, together with the expense of assessing and collecting the same, upon
the property upon which the alarm system is located, and cause the assessment
to be certified to the County Auditor for collection.
 
   (i)   Any device designed to emit an alarm upon detection of smoke, fire or
unauthorized intrusion shall constitute a nuisance if twelve (12) or more false
alarms are emitted and reported to the Police or Fire Departments, or both, in
any twelve (12) month period. The Law Director may take appropriate civil or
criminal action to abate such nuisance.
   (j)    Audible alarms which emit an audible signal for more than ten
consecutive minutes are hereby prohibited and declared to be a public nuisance.
In addition to other penalties provided by law, upon the failure of any system
user to remove or abate such nuisance, the Building Inspector or any member of
the Police Department may cause such nuisance to be removed or abated. Such
removal or abatement may include the seizure and/or destruction of property
constituting or used in the maintenance of the nuisance, for which the City,
its officers and employees shall have no liability. Any person failing to
remove or abate a nuisance as stated herein, shall be liable to the City for
any and alt costs of such removal or abatement, which costs may be recovered by
a proceeding instituted in any Court of competent jurisdiction.
   (k)    Automatic dialing devices are prohibited.
(Ord. 1998-70. Passed 12-10-98.)
715.10 EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS; OPERATION AND SERVICE.
   (a)    All equipment used in installations for which a permit is required
shall meet the applicable standards of the Underwriters Laboratories and/or the
National Fire Protection Association and/or other recognized industry standard.
The applicant may be required to submit evidence of the reliability and
suitability of the equipment to be installed.
   (b)    The sensory mechanism used in connection with such devices shall be
designed, installed and adjusted to suppress false indication of fire or
intrusion so that the device shall not be activated by impulses due to
transient pressure change of water pipes, short flashes of light, wind noises
such as rattling or vibrating doors or windows, vehicular noises adjacent to
the installation or other forces unrelated to genuine alarms, unless otherwise
accepted as provided herein Section
715.05(c)(2).
   (c)    All components comprising such device must be maintained by the owner
or lessee in good repair to assure reliability of operation.
 
   (d)    Each alarm equipment supplier that sells or leases to a person an
automatic protection device which is installed on such person's premises within
the City shall furnish such person with instructions as to the manner in which
the device operates, along with maintenance instructions.
   (e)    Each alarm equipment supplier shall also furnish the Chief of Police
and/ or Chief of the Fire Department with a copy of instructions as to the way
the device operates. If the Chief of Police and/or Chief of the Fire Department
find such to be incomplete, unclear or otherwise inadequate, he may require the
alarm equipment supplier to have the same revised to meet his approval and then
promptly have copies distributed to the persons for whom installations of such
devices are made.
   (f)    Each alarm equipment supplier that sells or leases to a person an
automatic protection device which is installed on such person's premises within
the City must provide for receiving calls for service directly or through an
agent on a twenty-four hour basis seven days a week and shall respond to such
calls within eight hours of the time they are received.
 
   (g)    At the time of installation each alarm equipment supplier shall
furnish to the person for whom an automatic protection device has been
installed written information as to how service can be obtained at any time,
including telephone number to call the service. Such person shall be
responsible for having the device repaired as quickly as possible after he
learns, either from his own sources or from notification by the City, that the
device is not working properly.
   (h)    The Chief of Police and the Chief of the Fire Department or any
officer designated by them shall have the authority, at reasonable times and
upon oral notice, to enter upon any premises within the City to inspect the
installation and operation of an automatic protection device or signaling
device; the purpose of which is to report an emergency to the Police and/or
Fire Station.
   (i)    All equipment, the use of or installation of which is subject to this
chapter, shall be maintained in good operating condition. The Chief of Police
or the Chief of the Fire Department may require that repairs be made whenever
he has determined that such are necessary to assure proper operation.
 
   (j)    Audible alarms, as defined in Section
715.05(a), shall be equipped to automatically deactivate so that no audible
signal is emitted longer than ten consecutive minutes after each activation.
(Ord. 1998-70. Passed 12-10-98.)
715.11 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   Failure to comply with the terms and conditions of this chapter may result
in license revocation.
(Ord. 1998-70. Passed 12-10-98.)
715.12 APPEAL OF LICENSE REVOCATION; DENIAL OF LICENSE.
   (a)    No person or persons engaging in the alarm business in the City shall
fail to comply with the order of the Chief of Police under this chapter.
 
   (b)    Any person(s) engaged in an alarm business who is denied a license to
operate in the City, or whose license is revoked, may appeal to the Mayor. A
notice of appeal, signed by the applicant, shall be fled with the Chief of
Police and shall set forth the reasons for the appeal in writing. It must be
filed within ten (10) days after the date of the denial or revocation.
   (c)    The Mayor or the Mayor's designee shall conduct a hearing within
thirty (30) days of receipt of the appeal. At the hearing, the appellant may be
heard in his or her defense in person or by counsel and may offer evidence on
his or her behalf The person conducting the hearing shall report findings and a
recommendation to the Mayor.
 
   (d)    The Safety Director shall review such findings and the
recommendation, and after full deliberation shall accept, modify or reject the
decision of the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 1998-70. Passed 12-10-98.)
715.13 NONLIABILITY OF CITY.
   The issuance of any permit or permits under the authority of this chapter
shall not constitute an acceptance by the City of any liability to maintain any
equipment, to answer alarms or for anything in connection with installation,
use or operation of the systems regulated by this chapter.
(Ord. 1998-70. Passed 12-10-98.)
715.14 RULES AND REGULATIONS; ENFORCEMENT.
   The Director of Public Safety or his authorized representative shall make
and enforce such rules and regulations as he may deem necessary for the
enforcement of the provisions of this chapter and for the proper determination
and collection of fees and charges provided for herein.
(Ord. 1998-70. Passed 12-10-98.)
715.99 PENALTY.
   (a)    In addition to the other penalties provided by law, any person, firm
or corporation whose residence or business has been equipped with an emergency
alarm system as described in Section
715.08 without first meeting the terms ofthis chapter shall be deemed guilty of
a minor misdemeanor and fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor
less that fifty dollars ($50.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed
each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
 
   (b)    In addition to the other penalties provided by law, whoever violates
or fails to comply with any other provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars
($100.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each
day during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
(Ord. 1998-70. Passed 12-10-98.)
 
CHAPTER 717
Riding Academies
 
717.01   Definitions.
717.02   Permit required.
717.03   Application for permit.
717.04   Issuance of permit.
717.05   Permit for each calendar year.
717.06   Duties of permittees.
717.07   Inspection.
717.08   Revocation of permit.
717.09   Prohibition against violation; injunctions.
717.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Animal nuisance conditions - see GEN. OFF.
505.01
Keeping horses - see BLDG. Ch.
1343
 
 
717.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, “riding academy” or “riding stable” means any
business of livery or boarding stable where, as a part of such business, horses
are rented to the general public. (Ord. 1977- 4. Passed 3-10-77.)
 
717.02 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person, firm, group, corporation, association or organization shall
operate or cause or permit to be operated a riding academy without first
obtaining a permit to do so from the Director of Public Safety.
(Ord. 1977-4. Passed 3-10-77.)
 
717.03 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
   An application for a permit shall be in writing on a form provided by the
Director of Public Safety. The application shall include the following
information:
   (a)   The name, address and telephone number of the owner of the property
where the riding academy business is located and the name and address of the
owner of the business.
   (b)   The address and telephone number of the riding academy.
   (c)   The name, address, age and job title of each employee of the riding
academy.
   (d)   An inventory, with descriptions and ages included, of all horses kept
at the riding academy.
   (e)   The date upon which such riding academy commenced its operations.
   (f)   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former subsection (f) hereof was repealed by Ordinance
1997-10A.
   (g)   Where the applicant is other than an individual, the name, address and
telephone number of an individual charged with management of the riding
academy.
   (h)   Such other information as the Director may reasonably require.
      (Ord. 1977-4. Passed 3-10-77; Ord. 1997-10A. Passed 6-12-97.)
 
717.04 ISSUANCE OF PERMIT.
   The Director of Public Safety shall issue a permit or renewal thereof to
each riding academy when the following conditions have been met:
   (a)   The applying riding academy has satisfactorily completed an
application form.
   (b)   The applying riding academy has tendered the permit fee.
   (c)   Any riding academy applying for a permit renewal has committed no
violations of any of the provisions of this chapter in the thirty day period
immediately preceding such application for renewal.
      (Ord. 1977-4. Passed 3-10-77; Ord. 1997-10A. Passed 6-12-97.)
 
717.05 PERMIT FOR EACH CALENDAR YEAR.
   The permit required under this chapter and each renewal thereof shall be
valid for the calendar year in which it is issued and may be renewed on an
annual basis thereafter.
   A fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) is hereby established for the original
issuance of a permit.
   A fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) is hereby established for each annual
renewal of a permit previously issued under the authority of this chapter.
(Ord. 1977-4. Passed 3-10-77.)
 
717.06 DUTIES OF PERMITTEES.
   Every person, firm or corporation holding a permit or renewal of a permit
under the authority of this chapter shall:
   (a)   Maintain a daily record of all accidents involving damage to property
or injury to persons and including the name and address of the person or
persons hiring the horse or horses involved in such accident, the location of
the accident, the names and addresses of each person sustaining damage to
property or bodily injury. Such records shall be open to public inspection.
   (b)   Maintain a daily record of the names and addresses of each person
hiring a horse from the permittee.
   (c)   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former subsection (c) hereof was repealed by Ordinance
1997- 10A.)
   (d)   Require each horse owned by such permittee at all times to be confined
upon the premises of the permittee or under the reasonable control of some
person.
   (e)   Maintain in a reasonably clean and sanitary condition all stables,
yards, corrals and other places where horses are kept.
   (f)   Authorize inspections of the permit, premises and record by the
Director of Public Safety or his representative at all reasonable times.
      (Ord. 1977-4. Passed 3-10-77; Ord. 1997-10A. Passed 6-12-97.)
 
717.07 INSPECTION.
   The Director of Public Safety or his representative is authorized to enter
upon and inspect the premises and required records of any permittee to
determine whether the permittee is in compliance with the provisions of this
chapter. The making of an application for a permit under this chapter shall
constitute a waiver of objection to any inspection or entry made pursuant to
this section. (Ord. 1977-4. Passed 3-10-77.)
 
717.08 REVOCATION OF PERMIT.
   The Director of Public Safety is authorized and directed to revoke any
original or renewal of a permit issued under this chapter upon notice and
hearing for any of the following causes:
   (a)   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the
application for permit or renewal thereof.
   (b)   Any violation of this chapter.
   (c)   Conviction of the applicant for any crime or violation of Municipal
ordinance involving moral turpitude. (Ord. 1977-4. Passed 3-10-77.)
 
717.09 PROHIBITION AGAINST VIOLATION; INJUNCTIONS.
   No person, firm or corporation shall violate any of the provisions of this
chapter. In the event of any such violation or imminent threat thereof, the
City, in addition to any remedies provided by law, may institute a suit for
preliminary and/or permanent injunction to prevent or terminate such violation.
(Ord. 1982-14. Passed 5-27-82.)
 
717.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) for a first offense; and for each subsequent offense not less than
two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than one thousand dollars
($1,000). A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 1997-10A. Passed 6-12-97.)
 
CHAPTER 745
Private Policemen
 
745.01   Private policeman defined.
745.02   Uniform.
745.03   Registration of weapons and certification.
745.04   Registration of private policemen.
745.05   Insurance.
745.06   Indemnity.
745.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
State law provisions - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4749
Rules - see OAC Ch. 1301: 4-5
Private policemen for multiple dwelling - see BLDG.
1349.19
 
 
745.01 PRIVATE POLICEMAN DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, “private policeman” means any person, not a member
of the Police or Fire Department of the City, who is employed as a police
officer, watchman, security guard or in any similar capacity and who wears a
military style uniform.
(Ord. 1976-30. Passed 6-10-76.)
 
745.02 UNIFORM.
   Any person acting as a private policeman with the limits of the City shall
wear a green, tan or grey uniform.
   No person not a member of the Police or Fire Department of the City shall
wear a uniform cap, badge or buttons similar to or in imitation of the official
uniform at the time in use by the members of such Departments. The use of
Police blue is specifically prohibited.
(Ord. 1976-20. Passed 6-10-76.)
 
745.03 REGISTRATION OF WEAPONS AND CERTIFICATION.
   Any hand gun or other weapon that will be carried by any private policeman
within the limits of the City shall be registered with the Chief of Police. No
private policeman shall carry a hand gun or other weapon while on duty as a
private policeman unless he has first obtained a certificate pursuant to Ohio
R.C. 109.78 or completed twenty years of active duty as a peace officer as
defined in Ohio R.C. 109.71.
(Ord. 1976-30. Passed 6-10-76.)
 
745.04 REGISTRATION OF PRIVATE POLICEMEN.
   No person shall act as a private policeman, or hold himself out as a private
policeman within the limits of the City unless he has first been registered
with the Chief of Police. To apply for such registration the applicant shall
submit the following information on such forms as are designed by the Chief:
   (a)   Name;
   (b)   Age;
   (c)   Social Security number;
   (d)   Current address and all other addresses at which the applicant has
resided in the past five years;
   (e)   A brief statement of the applicant’s qualifications, training and
prior experience;
   (f)   The name and address of the applicant’s employer;
   (g)   The address where the applicant will be employed and a description of
the services he will perform;
   (h)   A photostatic copy of the certificate issued by the Ohio Peace
Officers Training Council for any man that will be carrying a handgun or other
weapon while employed as a private policeman in the City, unless he has
completed twenty years of active duty as a peace officer, as defined in Ohio
R.C. 109.71;
   (i)   The names and addresses of two character references.
   The Chief is authorized to conduct an investigation into the background of
each applicant. No applicant shall be registered if upon investigation the
Chief reasonably determines that such applicant is not a person of suitable
character.
(Ord. 1976-30. Passed 6-10-76.)
 
745.05 INSURANCE.
   Every private policeman shall provide, along with his application for
registration as a private policeman, proof that he is insured by a policy or
policies of comprehensive general liability insurance in an amount of at least
three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000) for any and all claims arising out of
his activities as a private policeman or activities incidental or related
thereto. (Ord. 1976-30. Passed 6-10-76.)
 
745.06 INDEMNITY.
   Every private policeman, his employer and the owner of the premises where
the private policeman is to perform his duties shall agree to indemnify and
hold harmless the City, its agents, servants and employees, against any and all
claims arising out of such private policeman’s activities as a private
policeman or activities incidental or related thereto.
(Ord. 1976-30. Passed 6-10-76.)
 
745.99 PENALTY.
   Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be
guilty of a minor misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed
each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 1976-30.
Passed 6-10-76.)
 
CHAPTER 749
Public Picnics, Carnivals and Other Exhibitions
749.01    Definitions.
749.02    License required; fee.
749.03    Requirements for license.
749.04    Noise, nuisance and crowd control.
749.05    Exceptions to licensing requirements.
749.99    Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Regulation of shows and games; trafficking in tickets - see Ohio
         R.C. 715.48
      Power to regulate commercial amusements - see Ohio R.C.
         715. 51, 715.61
      Licensing shows or performances - see Ohio R.C. 715.63
      Loud musical noises - see GEN. OFF.
509.09
749.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following words shall have the
following meanings ascribed to them respectively:
   (a)    "Person" includes all persons, natural and artificial, and includes
but is not limited to private corporations, partnerships, associations,
employers, lessees, lessors, managers, agents, owners or assignors.
   (b)    "Public picnics, carnivals and other exhibitions" hereinafter
referred to as an "event" includes but is not limited to any event to which the
public is encouraged to attend or invited and for which the public pays a fee,
price or charge for admission or from which any person charges or receives any
compensation for the sale of food, beverage or other merchandise or from which
any person charges or receives any compensation for rides, exhibits, dances or
other forms of amusement.
   (c)    "Place" of picnic, carnival or exhibition shall include within any
structure, temporary or otherwise, or out in the open; or within or under any
canvas, tent or pavilion. (Ord. 1985-3. Passed 3-14-85.)
749.02 LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   No person shall give, conduct, produce, present or offer any public event
without first securing from the office of the Director of Public Safety a
license therefore and paying a license fee as follows:
 
Expected Attendance Fee Per Day
Less than 50        $10.00
51 - 100            15.00
101 - 300           25.00
301 or more         50.00
 
   The license and/or fees required by this chapter shall be in addition to any
other licenses and/or fees or charges required by the City Code or the general
laws of the State of Ohio. (Ord. 1985-3. Passed 3-14-85.)
749.03 REQUIREMENTS FOR LICENSE.
   In order for any person to obtain the license required in Section
749.02, that person shall have filed and approved with the office of the
Director of Public Safety in such form as required by the City, the following:
   (a)    A plan or diagram drawn to scale showing the available parking
arrangements to accommodate the proposed number of persons attending which
diagram shall have been submitted to and approved by the Fire Chief. The
parking to be provided shall be based on a ratio of three occupants per
vehicle. Any designated parking area must be maintained in a usable and
accessible condition. In determining the sufficiency of proposed parking no
consideration shall be given to nearby parking required by law for permanent
commercial structures at or near the site for which license application is
made. The proposed parking shall be located on, or on property contiguous to,
the proposed picnic site and shall not be separated from such site by any
dedicated public street or highway.
   (b)    A plan or diagram drawn to scale stating the total approved number of
persons attending such event with a plan as to the evacuation of such event in
case of a fire or other emergency; such plan to be submitted to and approved by
the Fire Chief.
   (c)    A statement as to crowd control and security in order to prevent
damage or destruction of any neighbor's property and a plan of traffic control.
The plans to be submitted to and approved by the Chief of Police.
   (d)    The results of a noise level test conducted at or near to the subject
location on the site of such event which test shall certify the average audible
level of noise, expressed in decibels, that such site experiences without such
event being in process. A statement, approved by the Chief of Police as to
noise level control so that the audible level of noise shall not exceed 1.5
times the average audible level as determined pursuant to this subsection.
   (e)    A statement of the hours that the event shall be open but in no case
shall the event commence prior to 10 a.m. or continue past 11 p.m.
   (f)    A current certificate of testing of all equipment, installations and
wiring issued by the City Fire Department and Electrical Inspector; such
certificate to demonstrate that within the last six months such equipment,
installations and wiring has been inspected and tested for safety by such
safety inspectors.
   (g)    An accord certificate of insurance signed by an insurance company
licensed to do business in the state of Ohio which shows that coverage is in
full force and effect in limits not less than five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000); except that where the event shall contain any rides or form of
transportation, the limits shall be not less than two million dollars
($2,000,000); with coverage for all the following on a comprehensive form:
      (1)    Premises liability;
      (2)    Products completed operations liability;
      (3)    Liquor liability insurance, if appropriate, for the sale and
distribution of all alcoholic beverages;
      (4)    Motor vehicle liability insurance;
      (5)    Blanket contractual liability insurance;
      (6)    Personal injury liability;
      (7)    Employers liability insurance;
      (8)    With certification that the City shall have thirty days advance
notice of cancellation, nonrenewal or change in the coverages or limits
contained in such policy or policies.
   (h)    No license shall be issued to any applicant who has violated the
terms and conditions of a prior license issued under the authority of this
chapter within thirty days of such (additional) application.
      (Ord. 1985-3. Passed 3-14-85.)
749.04 NOISE, NUISANCE AND CROWD CONTROL.
   (a)    No event shall produce or allow production of noise levels which
exceed 1.5
times the average noise level as certified pursuant to Section
749.03(d).
 
   (b)    No persons, firms or corporations, licensed under this chapter, shall
trespass
upon or shall permit, encourage, allow, assist and/or allow the public
attending such event to trespass upon the property of another.
 
   (c)    No person shall permit or encourage the overcrowding of any
structure, temporary or otherwise, or within or under any canvas, tent or
pavilion.
 
   (d)    In the event that subsections (a), (b) or (c) hereof are violated the
Safety Director, Chief of Police or Chief of Fire shall immediately notify the
person or persons responsible for such event and allow them reasonable time,
not to exceed ten minutes, to alleviate such violation. If such violation
continues, or resumes once abated, such official shall take such action or
actions as appropriate to immediately terminate the violation, or if the
violation cannot be terminated, to terminate the entire event.
   (e)    In addition to any other remedies provided by law, the Law Director
is hereby authorized to commence suit in the Common Pleas Court for Lake County
to enjoin any violation or threatened violation of the provisions of this
chapter.
(Ord. 1985-3. Passed 3-14-85.)
749.05 EXCEPTIONS TO LICENSING REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    No license fee shall be required of any person under the authority of
this chapter if the Director of Public Safety determines that any and all
profit to be made at such event shall be for the benefit of any organization or
person which is a charitable, religious, fraternal or eleemosynary
organization.
 
   (b)    No event which is a normal part of a business, club, church or school
activity by virtue of the fact that all activities take place within an
approved building for which a valid occupancy permit has been issued which
building is in compliance with the fire safety code and provides sufficient
parking as required by Section
749.03(a).
   (c)    No permit shall be required under this section for events to be held
on property owned by the City.
 
   (d)    No permit shall be required under this chapter for persons, firms or
corporations whose primary activity is the sale of carry-out food without the
sale of alcoholic beverages by the glass. (Ord. 1985-3. Passed 3-14-85.)
749.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be
deemed committed each day on which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 1985-3. Passed 3-14-85.)
 
CHAPTER 753
Mechanical Amusement Devices and Game Rooms
 
753.01   Definitions.
753.02   License display required.
753.03   Application for amusement device license.
753.04   Mechanical device license fee.
753.05   Game room license required.
753.06   Game room license application; approval or disapproval.
753.07   Game room license fee.
753.08   Interior requirements.
753.09   Supervision.
753.10   Hours.
753.11   Control of sound levels.
753.12   License revocation or suspension.
753.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Disturbing the peace - see GEN. OFF.
509.03
Gambling - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
517
Making or using slugs - see GEN. OFF.
545.11
Tampering with coin machines - see GEN. OFF.
545.12
 
 
753.01 DEFINITIONS.
     As used in this Chapter, certain words and terms are defined as follows:
   
   (a)   "Game Room" means a building, room enclosure, premises, place or
establishment in the City which contains more than six mechanical, electrically
and/or electronically operated amusement devices, other than telephones,
jukeboxes or coin-operated rides, which are used for the purpose of public
entertainment through the operation, use or play, or any table game or device
commonly known as mechanical, electric, and/or electronic games which are
operated by placing therein any card, coin, plate, disc, plug, key, token of
value and/or by the payment of a fee.
   (b)   "Decibels" means a unit for the measurement of relative sound levels
as indicated by a sound level meter conforming with the American Standards
Association Specification Z.24.3 - 1944.
   (c)   "Director of Public Safety" means the duly appointed or acting
Director of Public Safety of the City of Willoughby Hills, Ohio.
   (d)   "Mechanical, Electrically, and/or Electronically Operated Amusement
Device" means any coin operated, computer, device or instrument, other than a
telephone, jukebox or coin operated ride, which upon the insertion of a card,
coin, plate, disc, plug, key, token of value, and/or payment of a fee, operates
or may be operated for use as a game, contest of skill or amusement, of any
description regardless of whether said device is used for gambling as defined
in the Ohio Revised Code. For the purposes of this Chapter, however, nothing
contained herein shall apply to the operation of coin operated pool tables. As
used in this Chapter, and except where more specifically delineated, the term
"electrical" shall include the term "electronic" and the term "electrically"
shall include the term "electronically".
   (e)   “Jukebox" means any music vending machine, contrivance or device,
which upon the insertion of a card, coin, slug, token, plate disc, or key in to
any slot, crevice or other opening, or by the payment of any price, operates or
may be operated by the emission of songs, music or similar amusement.
      (Ord. 2010-30. Passed 8-4-10.)
 
753.02 LICENSE DISPLAY REQUIRED.
   No person shall display or exhibit a mechanical amusement device without
having first obtained a license therefore from the Director of Public Safety as
provided by this Chapter. One certificate license shall be issued, indicating
number of devices licensed for use in the establishment. This certificate of
licensure must be prominently displayed within the boundaries of the
establishment. (Ord. 2010-30. Passed 8-4-10.)
 
753.03 APPLICATION FOR AMUSEMENT DEVICE LICENSE.
   (a)   Application for a license to display a mechanical amusement device
shall be made to the Director of Public Safety upon such forms as prepared by
the Director of Public Safety. The application shall be made by the owner or
proprietor of the business or place at which the mechanical amusement device is
to be displayed. The application shall state the name of the owner of the place
or business, the address of the place at which the mechanical device is to be
displayed, the residence address of the owner, the serial number and name of
manufacturer of the mechanical amusement device, the owner of the mechanical
amusement device, the name and address of the distributor of the mechanical
amusement device, the nature of the business in conjunction with which the
mechanical amusement device is to be displayed and such other information as
may be required by the Director of Public Safety.
 
   (b)   No application for an amusement device license shall be granted and no
amusement device license shall be issued until the applicant has furnished to
the Director of Public Safety, evidence of public liability insurance for
bodily injury in the minimum amount of one hundred thousand/three hundred
thousand dollars ($100,000/$300,000) and for property damage in the minimum
amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000).
(Ord. 1981-44. Passed 12-23-81.)
 
753.04 MECHANICAL DEVICE LICENSE FEE.
   Any applicant to which a license to display a mechanical amusement device is
granted shall pay a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each mechanical amusement
device per month. The number of devices licensed for use in the establishment
is indicated on the licensure and shall be amended as machines are added or
deleted. This certificate of licensure must be prominently displayed within the
boundaries of the establishment.
(Ord. 2010-40. Passed 12-9-10.)
 
753.05 GAME ROOM LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm, corporation or association shall engage in the business of
operating a game room within the limits of the City without first having
applied for and obtained from the Director of Public Safety a license as
provided for in this chapter.
(Ord. 1981-44. Passed 12-23-81.)
 
753.06 GAME ROOM LICENSE APPLICATION; APPROVAL OR DISAPPROVAL.
   (a)   Application for the license shall be made to the Director of Public
Safety on forms to be prescribed by him, and shall state the name and address
of the applicant, if individuals, and if a firm or partnership, the names,
residences and occupations of the manager and each member of the firm or
partnership, and if a corporation, the names of its officers and manager, and
such other information as the Director of Public Safety may reasonably require.
 
   (b)   The Director of Public Safety shall transmit such application for
inspection and investigation to the Building Inspector, Fire Chief and Police
Chief. The Building Inspector, Fire Chief and Police Chief each shall, after
such inspection and investigation as they may deem necessary, make a report
with their recommendation for approval or disapproval of such application.
There shall be submitted with and as a part of the application, plans showing
the pertinent details of the game room and building as required by the Building
Inspector. These plans shall be submitted in sufficient copies for distribution
by the Director of Public Safety to the Building Inspector, Fire Chief and
Police Chief and all members of the Planning and Zoning Commission.
 
   (c)   If the application and the plans are approved by the Planning and
Zoning Commission, Building Inspector, Fire Chief and Police Chief, the
Director of Public Safety shall issue a license on payment of the required fee.
 
   (d)   The application for a license shall be rejected if the report
submitted thereon shows that any person named in the application is not of good
moral character of that the game room sought to be licensed does not comply
with the zoning, building, health and fire regulations applicable thereto.
 
   (e)   No game room license application shall be approved and no game room
license issued until the applicant has furnished evidence of public liability
insurance for bodily injury in the minimum amount of one hundred thousand/three
hundred thousand dollars ($100,000/$300,000), and for property damage in the
minimum amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000). (Ord. 1981-44. Passed 12-
23-81.)
 
753.07 GAME ROOM LICENSE FEE.
   Any person, firm, corporation or association to which a license is granted
shall pay an annual fee of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). All licenses
granted under the provisions of Section
753.05 shall expire twelve (12) months from the date of issuance. The license
shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the game room for which it is
issued. No transfer of any license shall be permitted.
(Ord. 2010-40. Passed 12-9-10.)
 
753.08 INTERIOR REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   The Chief of the Fire Department is hereby authorized to provide and
promulgate rules and regulations requiring the interior arrangements for game
rooms and mechanical amusement devices in a manner consistent with public
safety and all applicable federal, state and local ordinances and regulations.
 
   (b)   The interior of the game room shall also contain sufficient toilet
facilities as required and defined by the current provisions of the Ohio Basic
Building Code.
(Ord. 1981-44. Passed 12-23-81.)
 
753.09 SUPERVISION.
   Each operator of a game room shall provide at least one or more responsible
adult(s), twenty-one years old or older, as a supervisor who shall be readily
identifiable and on duty at all times the game room is open for business. Such
supervisor shall maintain the decorum of the game room and keep the aisles free
for passage throughout the game room and shall further control the amount of
noise as required by this chapter.
(Ord. 1981-44. Passed 12-23-81.)
 
753.10 HOURS.
   The hours of operation of the game room shall not commence earlier than 9:00
a.m., nor shall they extend beyond the hour of 2:30 a.m. except that if the
licensed premises are also licensed for any purpose by the State of Ohio then
the hours permitted hereunder shall be those hours permitted by the State.
(Ord. 2010-40. Passed 12-9-10.)
 
753.11 CONTROL OF SOUND LEVELS.
   The operator or supervisor of a game room shall not permit a sound level in
excess of ninety decibels for thirty seconds or more of any minute. The sound
control shall be determined by a sound level meter conforming with the American
Standards Association Specification Z.24.3-1944, using the weighted network C
and measured at a point not less than three feet from the mechanical amusement
device while in continuous operation.
(Ord. 1981-44. Passed 12-23-81.)
 
753.12 LICENSE REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION.
   The Director of Public Safety, upon recommendation of the Building
Inspector, or Chief of the Fire Department, or Chief of the Police Department,
may at any time revoke or suspend licenses granted under authority of this
chapter for the failure to comply with the terms of this chapter or any laws,
ordinances or rules of the State or the City. In addition thereto, the Director
of Public Safety shall have the full power and authority to revoke the license
of any firm, person or corporation or association who is convicted of a
violation of any criminal law of the state or the City.
(Ord. 1981-44. Passed 12-23-81.)
753.99  PENALTY.
   Any firm, person, corporation or association which violates any of the
provisions of this chapter shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars
($100.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each
day during or on which such violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 1981-44. Passed 12-23-81.)
 
CHAPTER 755
Massage Establishments
 
755.01    Definitions.
755.02    Permit required.
755.03    Exemptions.
755.04    Permit application fee.
755.05    Content of application.
755.06    Application for masseur or masseuse permit.
755.07    Issuance of license or permit for massage establishment.
755.08    Approval or denial of application.
755.09    Waiver of application requirements.
755.10    Multiple massage establishments.
755.11    Posting of license or permit.
755.12    Register of employees.
755.13    Revocation or suspension of license.
755.14    Revocation of masseur or masseuse business permit.
755.15    Facilities.
755.16    Operating requirements.
755.17    Alcoholic beverages prohibited.
755.18    Hours.
755.19    Employment of masseur or masseuse.
755.20    Inspection required.
755.21    Prohibited conduct.
755.22    Transfer of permits.
755.23    Name and location of business.
755.24    Transfer of license or permit.
755.25    Effect of partial invalidity.
755.26    Patrons under age eighteen.
755.99    Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Obscenity and sex offenses - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
533
         Adult Entertainment - see P. & Z. Ch.
1163
755.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this Chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the following meanings unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning:
   (a)   "Applicant" means a person applying for a permit under this Chapter
and includes all partners, including limited partners of a partnership
applicant, any officer or director of a corporate applicant, and any
stockholder holding more than ten percent (10%) of the stock of a corporate
applicant.
   (b)   "Employee" means any person over eighteen years of age, other than the
masseurs or masseuses, who render any service in connection with the massage
business and receives compensation from the operator of the business or
patrons.
   (c)   "Licensee" means the person certified by the State Medical Board and
to whom the City has issued a license to own or operate a massage establishment
as defined herein.
   (d)   "Massage" means any method of pressure on or friction against, or
stroking, kneading, rubbing, tapping, pounding, vibrating or stimulating of the
external soft parts of the human body with the hands or with the aid of
mechanical or electrical apparatus or appliances with or without such
supplementary aids as rubbing alcohol, liniments, antiseptics, oils, powder,
creams, lotions, ointments or other such similar preparations commonly used in
the practice.
   (e)   "Massage establishment" means any establishment having a source of
income or compensation derived from the practice of massage as defined in
subsection (d) hereof and which has a fixed place of business where any person,
firm, association or corporation engages in or carries on any of the activities
as defined in subsection (d) hereof, or in connection with the provisions of
another legitimate service.
   (f)   "Massagist," "Masseur" or "Masseuse" means any person who, for any
consideration whatsoever, engages in the practice of massage, under a license
issued by the State of Ohio or upon completion of a court of instruction for a
period of not less than one (1) year and a minimum of six hundred (600) clock
hours at an approved school of massage therapy.
   (g)   "Outcall massage service" means any business, the function of which is
to engage in or carry on massages at a location designated by the customer or
client rather that at a massage establishment as defined in subsection (e)
hereof.
   (h)   "Patron" means any person eighteen years of age or older who receives
a massage under such circumstances that it is reasonably expected that he or
she will pay money or give any other consideration therefore; or any person
under eighteen years of age who receives a massage under such circumstances
that it is reasonably expected that he or she will pay money or give any other
consideration therefore, and who is referred for the massage by the written
prescription of a licensed medical doctor.
   (i)   "Permit" means that document issued by the City of Willoughby Hills
authorizing the operation of a massage establishment within its jurisdiction.
   (j)   "Permittee" means the operator of a massage establishment, to which a
permit has been issued to act in the capacity of a massagist, masseur or
masseuse, as defined in subsection (f) hereof.
   (k)   "Person" means any individual, partnership, firm, association, joint
stock company, corporation or combination of individuals of whatever form or
character.
   (l)   "Recognized school" means any school or educational institution
licensed to do business as a school or educational institution in the State of
Ohio or any school recognized by or approved by the State of Ohio and approved
or affiliated with the American Massage and Therapy Association, Inc., and
which has for its purpose the teaching of the theory, method, profession or
work of massage; which school requires a resident course of study not less than
seventy hours before the student shall be furnished with a diploma or
certificate of graduation from such school or institution of learning following
the successful completion of such course of study or learning.
   (m)   "Sexual or genital area" means the genitals, pubic area, anus or
perineum of any person, or the vulva or breasts of a female.
   (n)   "City" means the City of Willoughby Hills, Lake County, Ohio.
      (Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.02  PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (a)   Business Permit Required. No person shall engage in, conduct, or carry
on or permit to be engaged in, conducted or carried on, the business of a
massage establishment without first having obtained a valid massage
establishment permit from the City of Willoughby Hills pursuant to the
provisions of this Chapter for each and every separate office or place of
business conducted by such person.
(Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.03  EXEMPTIONS.
   This Chapter shall not apply to the following:
   (a)   Hospitals, nursing homes, sanitariums, Medicaid offices and public
health centers, physicians, surgeons, chiropractors, osteopaths, state
registered nurses, or physical therapists who are duly licensed to practice
their respective professions in the State of Ohio, or any person working under
the direct supervision of and in the presence of any such persons.
   (b)   Establishments owned and operated by a person licensed or registered
by the State of Ohio while performing his or her registered profession.
   (c)   Establishments that provide the services of a licensed cosmetologist,
registered barber, registered barber apprentice, or licensed chiropractor.
   (d)   As used in this section, "licensed" means licensed, certified, or
registered to practice by the State of Ohio.
      (Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.04 PERMIT APPLICATION FEE.
   (a)   Prior to operating a massage establishment within the City of
Willoughby Hills, every operation shall obtain a permit to operate from the
City. The permit to operate shall expire on December 31 following the date of
issuance and shall be renewed annually in the month of December and before the
first day of January of the next succeeding year.
   (b)   An annual permit fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be paid by
each massage establishment operating within the City of Willoughby Hills. An
application for a permit to operate a massage establishment shall be
accompanied by a fee in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00). Any change
of ownership shall require an application and permit with payment of associated
fees.
   (c)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to engage in
the business of operating a massage establishment within the City of Willoughby
Hills without a permit issued by the City to engage in such business. Such a
permit shall be displayed in a conspicuous place within the establishment.
   (d)   The failure or refusal of the applicant to promptly give the
information relevant to the investigation of the applicant or his or her
refusal to submit to or cooperate with any inspection required by this Chapter
shall constitute an admission by the applicant that he or she is ineligible for
such permit and shall be grounds for the denial thereof by the City.
(Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.05 CONTENT OF APPLICATION.
   Every applicant for a permit to maintain, operate or conduct a massage
establishment shall file an application under oath with the City upon a form
provided by the Building Department and pay a nonrefundable annual license fee,
which shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year or any part thereof. Upon
the application's receipt, the Building Department shall commence its
investigation and review. Copies of the application shall within five days also
be referred to the Fire Department and the Lake County Health District. The
departments shall within thirty (30) days inspect the premises proposed to be
operated as a massage establishment and shall make written verifications to the
Building Department concerning compliance with the Code provisions of the City.
The application shall further be reviewed by the Police Department for
investigation of the applicant's character and qualifications. Each application
shall contain the following information:
   (a)   A definition of the massage service to be provided.
   (b)   The location, mailing address and all telephone numbers where the
business is to be conducted.
   (c)   The name and residence address of each applicant:
      (1)   If applicant is a corporation, the names and addresses of each of
the officers and directors of such corporation and of each stockholder owning
more than ten percent (10%) of the stock of the corporation; and the address of
the corporation, itself, if different from the address of the massage
establishment.
      (2)   If applicant is a partnership, the names and residence addresses of
each of the partners including limited partners, and the address of the
partnership, itself, if different from the address of the massage
establishment.
   (d)   The two previous addresses immediately prior to the present address of
the applicant.
   (e)   Proof that the applicant is at least eighteen (18) years of age.
   (f)   Individual or partnership applicant's height, weight, color of eyes,
hair and sex.
   (g)   Copy of identification such as driver's license and Social Security
card.
   (h)   One portrait photograph of the applicant at least two (2) inches by
two (2) inches and a complete set of applicant's fingerprints both of which
shall be taken by the Police Department or its designated agent. If the
application is a corporation, one portrait photograph at least two (2) inches
by two (2) inches of all officers and managing agents of such corporation and a
complete set of the same officers' and agents' fingerprints which shall both be
taken by the Police Department or its designated agent. If the applicant is a
partnership, one front-face portrait photograph at least two (2) inches by two
(2) inches in size of each partner, including a limited partner in such
partnership, and a complete set of each partner or limited partner's
fingerprints both which shall be taken by the Police Department or its
designated agent.
   (i)   Business, occupation, or employment of the applicant for the three (3)
years immediately preceding the date of application.
   (j)   The massage or similar business license of the applicant; whether such
person, in previously operating in this City or another city or state has had a
business license revoked or suspended, the reason therefor, and the business
activity or occupation subsequent to such action or suspension or revocation.
   (k)   All criminal convictions other than misdemeanor traffic violations,
including the date of convictions, nature of the crime and place convicted.
   (l)   The name and address of each employee, masseur or masseuse who is or
will be employed by the applicant.
   (m)   Applicant must furnish a diploma or certificate of graduation from a
recognized school or other institution of learning wherein the method,
profession and work of massage is taught; provided, however, that if the
applicant will not himself or herself engage in the practice of massage as
defined herein, the applicant need not possess such diploma or certificate of
graduation from a recognized school or other institution of learning wherein
the method, profession and work of massage is taught.
   (n)   The name and address of any massage business or other establishment
owned or operated by any person whose name is required to be given in
subsection (c) hereof wherein the business or profession of massage is carried
on.
   (o)   A description of any other business to be operated on the same
premises or on an adjoining premises owned or controlled by the applicant.
   (p)   Authorization for the City, its agents and employees to seek
information and conduct an investigation into the truth of the statements set
forth in the application and the qualifications of the applicant for the
permit.
   (q)   Such other identification and information necessary to discover the
truth of the matters hereinbefore specified as required to be set forth in the
application.
   Upon completion of the above provided form and the furnishing of all
foregoing information the Building Department shall accept the application for
the necessary investigations.
   The holder of a massage establishment license shall notify the Building
Department of each change in any of the data required to be furnished by this
section within ten (10) days after such change occurs. (Ord. 2021-033. Passed
6-10-21.)
755.06  APPLICATION FOR MASSEUR OR MASSEUSE PERMIT.
   Application for a masseur or masseuse permit shall be made to the Building
Department in the same manner as provided above for massage establishment
licenses or permits, accompanied by the annual non-refundable massagist's
permit fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year or part thereof. The
application shall contain but be limited to the following:
   (a)   The business address and all telephone numbers where the massage is to
be practiced.
   (b)   Name and residence address, and all names, nicknames and aliases by
which the applicant has been known, including the two previous addresses
immediately prior to the present address of the applicant.
   (c)   Social Security Number, driver's license number, if any, and date of
birth.
   (d)   Applicant's weight, height, color of hair and eyes and sex.
   (e)   Written evidence that the applicant is at least eighteen years of age.
   (f)   A complete statement of all convictions of the applicant for any
felony or misdemeanor or violation of local ordinance, except misdemeanor
traffic violations.
   (g)   Fingerprints of the applicant taken by the Police Department.
   (h)   Two (2) front-face portrait photographs, taken by the Police
Department or its designated agent, within thirty (30) days of the date of
application and at least two (2) inches by two (2) inches.
   (i)   The name and address of the accredited school attended, the dates
attended, and a copy of the diploma or certificate of graduation awarded the
applicant showing the applicant has completed a course of instruction for a
period of not less than one year and a minimum of six hundred (600) clock hours
at an approved school of massage therapy or a copy of a current license issued
by the State of Ohio.
   (j)   The massage or similar business history and experience for the ten
(10) years prior to the date of application, including but not limited to
whether or not such person in previously operating in this City or another city
or state under license or permit, has had such license or permit denied,
revoked, or suspended and the reasons therefore, and the business activities or
occupations subsequent to such action of denial, suspension or revocation.
   (k)   A medical certificate signed by a physician, licensed to practice in
the State of Ohio, within seven (7) days of the date of the application. The
certificate shall state that the applicant was examined by the certifying
physician and that the applicant is free of communicable disease. The
additional information required by this subsection shall be provided at the
applicant's expense.
   (l)   Such other information, identification and physical examination of the
person deemed necessary by the Police Department or the Department's designated
agent in order to discover the truth of the matters hereinbefore required to be
set forth in the application.
   (m)   Authorization for the City, its agents and employees to seek
information and conduct an investigation into the truth of the statements set
forth in the application and the qualifications of the applicant for the
permit.
   (n)   Written declaration by the applicant, under penalty of perjury, that
the foregoing information contained in the application is true and correct,
such declaration being duly dated and signed in the City.
      (Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.07 ISSUANCE OF LICENSE OR PERMIT FOR MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENT.
   The results of all investigations conducted pursuant to this Chapter shall
be forwarded to the Building Department for review. The Building Department
shall issue a license for a massage establishment or a permit for a masseur or
masseuse, after determining that all requirements for a massage establishment
or masseur or masseuse permit described in this Chapter are met unless the
Building Department finds:
   (a)   The correct permit or license fee has not been tendered to the City
and in the case of a check, or bank draft, honored with payment upon
presentation.
   (b)   The operation, as proposed by the applicant, if permitted, would not
comply with all applicable laws, including but not limited to the City's fire,
building, zoning and/or health regulations.
   (c)   The applicant, if an individual; or any of the stockholders holding
more than ten percent (10%) of the stock of the corporation, any of the
officers or directors, if the applicant is a corporation; or any of the
partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership; or the
holder of any lien, of any nature, upon the business and/or the equipment used
therein; and the manager or other person principally in charge of the operation
of the business, have been convicted of any of the following offenses or
convicted of an offense outside the State of Ohio that would have constituted
any of the following offenses if committed within the State.
      (1)   An offense involving the use of force and violence upon the person
of another that amounts to a felony.
      (2)   An offense involving sexual misconduct.
   (d)   The applicant has knowingly made any false, misleading or fraudulent
statement of fact in the permit application or in any document required by the
City in conjunction therewith.
   (e)   The applicant had a massage business, masseur, masseuse, or other
similar permit or license denied, revoked or suspended by the City or any other
state or local agency within five years prior to the date of the application.
   (f)   The applicant, if an individual, or any of the officers and directors,
if the applicant is a corporation; or any of the partners, including limited
partners, if the applicant is a partnership, and the manager or other person
principally in charge of the operation of the business, is not over the age of
eighteen (18) years.
   (g)   The applicant has not complied with the requirements of this Chapter.
      (Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.08  APPROVAL OR DENIAL OF APPLICATION.
   The City shall act to approve or deny an application for a license or a
permit under this Chapter within a reasonable period of time, and in no event
shall the City act to approve or deny such license or permit later than ninety
(90) days from the date that such application was accepted by the Building
Department. Every license or permit issued pursuant to this Chapter will
terminate at the expiration of one (1) year from the date of its issuance
unless sooner suspended or revoked.
(Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.09  WAIVER OF APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS.
   The City may waive the requirements contained in Section
 755.06(i) and sections of this Chapter which incorporate Section
 755.06(i) if the applicant furnishes satisfactory evidence that he or she
attended not less than six hundred (600) hours of instruction in a school
within or outside of this State or in any foreign country that provides
education substantially equal to or in excess of the educational requirements
of this Chapter; in any event, the massagist, masseur or masseuse shall be
certified to practice massage by the State Medical Board. (Ord. 2021-033.
Passed 6-10-21.)
755.10  MULTIPLE MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS.
   Should any massage business have more than one location where the business
of massage is pursued, then a permit, stating both the address of the principal
place of business, and of the other location(s) shall be issued by the Finance
Department upon the tender of a license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
Licenses issued for other locations shall terminate on the same date as that of
the principal place of business, regardless of the date of issuance. (Ord.
2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.11 POSTING OF LICENSE OR PERMIT.
   (a)   Every masseur or masseuse shall prominently post the permit required
by this Chapter in his or her work area, which permit shall include the
photograph referred to in Section
 755.05(h).
   (b)   Every person, corporation, partnership or association licensed under
this Chapter shall display such license or permit in a prominent place, which
permit shall include the photograph referred to in Section
 755.06.
(Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.12  REGISTER OF EMPLOYEES.
   The licensee or person designated by the licensee of a massage establishment
shall maintain a register of all persons employed at any time as masseurs or
masseuses and their permit numbers. Such register shall be available at the
massage establishment to representatives of the City during regular business
hours.
(Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.13  REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE.
   Any permit or license issued for a massage establishment may be revoked or
suspended by the Board of Zoning Appeals after a hearing for good cause, or in
any case where any of the provisions of this Chapter are violated, or where an
employee of the permittee, including a masseur or masseuse, is engaged in any
conduct at the permitee's place of business which violates any of the
provisions of this Chapter or any state law which provides for criminal
prosecution, and the permittee has actual or constructive knowledge of such
violation, or the permittee has actual or constructive knowledge by due
diligence, or where an applicant has made a false statement on an application
for a permit under this Chapter, or in any case where the permittee or licensee
refused to permit any duly authorized building inspector or police officer to
inspect the premises or the operations therein.
   Notice of Revocation or Suspension shall be made by hand-delivery or by
certified mail, and shall contain therein the right to appeal before the Board
of Zoning Appeals by filing such appeal with the Secretary of the Board within
ten (10) days from receipt of the Notice of Revocation or Suspension, and shall
further state that failure to appeal within ten (10) days shall result in
permanent revocation or suspension.
(Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.14  REVOCATION OF MASSEUR OR MASSEUSE BUSINESS PERMIT.
   (a)   A masseur or masseuse registration issued by the Building Department
shall be revoked or suspended where it appears that the masseur or masseuse has
been convicted of a offense which would be cause for denial of a registration
upon an original application; has made a false statement on an application for
a registration, is under the age of eighteen (18) years; or has committed an
act in violation of this Chapter.
   (b)   The Building Department, in revoking or suspending a masseur or
masseuse registration, shall give the registration holder a written notice
specifying the grounds thereof. Such person may within ten (10) days of receipt
of such revocation or suspension file a written request for appeal with the
Clerk of that Board for a hearing before the Board of Zoning Appeals. The Board
after such hearing, may sustain, disapprove or modify such order.
(Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.15 FACILITIES.
   No license to conduct a massage establishment shall be issued unless an
inspection by the City confirms that the establishment complies with each of
the following minimum requirements:
   (a)   Construction of rooms used for toilets, tubs, steam baths and showers
shall be made waterproof with approved waterproofed materials and shall be
installed in accordance with the City Building Code and the Ohio Basic Building
Code. The City's Code shall prevail in case of conflict. Plumbing fixtures
shall be installed in accordance with the City Plumbing Code.
      (1)   Steam rooms and shower compartments shall have waterproof floors,
walls and ceilings approved by the City.
      (2)   Floors of wet and dry heat rooms shall be adequately pitched to one
or more floor drains properly connected to the sewer, with the exception that
dry heat rooms with wooden floors need not be required with pitched floors and
floor drains.
      (3)   A source of hot water shall be available within the immediate
vicinity of dry and wet heat rooms to facilitate cleaning.
   (b)   The premises shall have adequate equipment for disinfecting and
sterilizing non-disposable instruments and materials used in administering
massages. Such non-disposable instruments and materials shall be disinfected
after use on each patron.
   (c)   Closed cabinets shall be provided and used for the storage of clean
linen, towels, and other materials used in connection with administering
massages. All soiled linens, towels and other materials shall be kept in
properly covered containers or cabinets, which containers and cabinets shall be
kept separate from the clean storage areas.
   (d)   Toilet facilities shall be provided in convenient locations. When
employees and patrons of different sexes are on the premises at the same time,
separate toilet facilities shall be provided for each sex. A single water
closet per sex shall be provided for each twenty or more employees or patrons
of that sex on the premises at one time. Urinals may be substituted for water
closets after one water closet has been provided. Toilets shall be designated
as to the sex accommodated therein.
   (e)   Lavatories or washbasins provided with both hot and cold running water
shall be installed in either the toilet room or a vestibule immediately
adjacent therewith. Lavatories or washbasins shall be provided with soap and a
dispensers and with sanitary towels.
   (f)   The premises at all times shall meet the requirements of all
applicable building codes and fire prevention regulations.
      (Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.16 OPERATING REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Every portion of the massage establishment, including appliances and
apparatus, shall be kept clean and operated in a sanitary condition.
   (b)   Price rates for all services shall be prominently posted in the
reception area in a location available to all prospective customers.
   (c)   All employees, including masseurs and masseuses, shall be clean in
appearance and at all times wear clean, non-transparent outer garments,
covering the sexual and genital areas, whose use is restricted to the massage
establishment. A separate dressing room for each sex must be available on the
premises with individual lockers for each employee. Doors to such dressing
rooms shall open inward and shall be self-closing.
   (d)   All massage establishments shall be provided with clean, laundered
sheets and towels in sufficient quantity and shall be laundered after each use
thereof and stored in a sanitary manner.
   (e)   The sexual or genital area of patrons shall be covered by towels,
clothes or under garments when in the presence of an employee, masseur or
masseuse.
   (f)   All walls, ceilings, floors, pools, showers, bathtubs, steam rooms and
other physical facilities shall be in good repair and maintained in a clear and
sanitary condition. Wet and dry heat rooms, steam or vapor rooms or steam or
vapor cabinets, shower compartments and toilet rooms shall be thoroughly
cleaned each day the business is in operation. Bathtubs and showers shall be
thoroughly cleaned after each use. Where carpeting is used on the floors, it
shall be kept dry.
   (g)   Oil, creams, lotions or other preparations used in administering
massages shall be kept in a clean, closed container or cabinet.
   (h)   Eating in the massage work area shall not be permitted.
   (i)   Each masseur or masseuse shall wash his or her hands in hot running
water using proper soap or disinfectant before administering a massage to each
patron.
   (j)   No massage establishment granted a permit or license under the
provisions of this Chapter shall place, publish or distribute, or cause to be
placed, published or distributed any advertisement, picture or statement which
is known or through the exercise of reasonable care should be known to be
false, deceptive or misleading in order to induce any person to purchase or
utilize any professional massage service.
(Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.17 ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES PROHIBITED.
   No person shall sell, give, dispense, provide or keep, or cause to be sold,
given, dispensed, provided or kept, any alcoholic beverage, intoxicating
liquor, or controlled substance on the premises of any massage business.
(Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.18 HOURS.
   No massage establishment shall be kept open for any purposes between the
hours of 10:00 p.m., and 6:00 a.m.
(Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.19  EMPLOYMENT OF MASSEUR OR MASSEUSE.
   No person shall employ as a masseur or masseuse any person unless such
employee has obtained and has in effect a permit issued pursuant to this
Chapter.
(Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.20 INSPECTION REQUIRED.
   The appropriate officers or representatives from the Police Department and
Building Department shall be authorized to make inspections of each massage
establishment for the purposes of determining that the provisions of this
Chapter are fully complied with. If in the opinion of the Police Department,
the Building Department, or their authorized representatives, there is probable
cause to enter a massage establishment for the purpose of making inspections
and examinations pursuant to this Chapter, he or she shall request the owner or
occupant thereof to grant permission for such entry. If refused, he or she
shall inform the Building Department, which shall make application to a
Municipal Court for a search warrant showing the judge why the search warrant
should be issued for the purposes and requirements set forth in this Chapter.
(Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.21  PROHIBITED CONDUCT.
   (a)   No owner or operator of a massage establishment located in the City of
Willoughby Hills shall knowingly do any of the following:
      (1)   Employ an unregistered masseur or masseuse.
      (2)   Refuse to allow appropriate State or local authorities, including
members of the City's Police Department and Building Department, access to the
massage establishment for any health or safety inspection or license
requirement conducted pursuant to this Chapter.
      (3)   Employ any person under the age of eighteen.
      (4)   Record in any medium the delivery of a massage to any person or
record in any medium the disrobing or showering of any person.
   (b)   No person employed in a massage establishment located in the City of
Willoughby Hills shall knowingly do any of the following in the performance of
duties at the massage establishment:
      (1)   Place his or her hand upon, touch with any part of his or her body,
fondle in any manner, or massage the sexual or genital area of any other
person.
      (2)   Perform, offer, or agree to perform any act which would require the
touching of the sexual or genital area of any other person.
      (3)   Touch, offer or agree to touch the sexual or genital area of any
person with any mechanical or electrical apparatus or appliance.
      (4)   Wear unclean clothing, no clothing, transparent clothing, or
clothing that otherwise reveals the sexual or genital areas of the masseur or
masseuse.
      (5)   Uncover or allow the sexual or genital area of any other person to
be uncovered while providing massages.
      (6)   Perform, offer or agree to perform non-medical massage with or
without compensation to any individual under the age of eighteen years old.
         (Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.22 TRANSFER OF PERMITS.
   No permit for the operation of a massage establishment issued pursuant to
the provisions of this Chapter shall be transferable except with the written
consent of the Police Department and Building Department, respectively;
provided, however, that upon the death or incapacity of the permittee, the
massage establishment may continue in business for a reasonable period of time
not to exceed sixty (60) days to allow for an orderly transfer of the permit.
(Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.23 NAME AND LOCATION OF BUSINESS.
   No person granted a license pursuant to this Chapter shall operate the
massage establishment under a name not specified in the permit, nor shall any
person conduct business under any designation or location not specified in the
permit.
(Ord. 2021-033. Passed 6-10-21.)
755.24 TRANSFER OF LICENSE OR PERMIT.
   No license or permit shall be transferable except with the consent of the
City and thereafter ratified by the Planning Commission of the City. An
